channel.title: Combined Politepol Feed
channel.description: Merged feed from multiple Politepol sources

item.title: Ajit Pawar plane crash: Who were the 2 pilots killed in the mishap?
Can a Chinese drug help India tackle Nipah virus?
In Graphics | Remembering Ajit Pawar, Maharashtra's deputy chief minister and 'dada'
Love for luxury and scandals… The life of South Korea’s former first lady Kim Keon Hee
Why has the euro crossed $1.20 against the US dollar? Why does it matter?
Ajit Pawar’s death shakes Maharashtra politics. What could be the fallout?
Trump’s Board of Peace: A new world order without the United Nations?
item.description: The White House, bypassing the UN, has invited more than 60 countries to join the Donald Trump-headed Board of Peace in Davos

item.title: A strategic confluence: Why the India-EU trade deal matters
item.description: The India-EU trade deal is less about romance than realism. Like the sangam, it brings together two currents that need each other more than they admit

item.title: Germany recognises the China challenge — but still hesitates
item.description: In today’s geopolitical environment, realism delayed is realism denied. Germany learnt that lesson the hard way with Russia. The question now is whether it has learnt it in time with China

item.title: Gaza Peace Board: Why India must reject Trump’s offer
item.description: India should not contribute to the further erosion of multilateral norms. Historically, it has maintained a balanced position on the Palestine–Israel question, grounded in its belief in the viability of a two-state solution; it must now adhere to this position firmly and consistently

item.title: How Xi Jinping’s power grab spells global looming crisis
item.description: As Xi Jinping amasses unprecedented power through relentless purges, China risks internal chaos and global instability in an era of one-man rule.

item.title: Xi’s China: When too much control becomes a systemic risk
item.description: China’s future depends on whether Xi Jinping's centralised model can reintroduce internal correction mechanisms, tolerate limited decentralisation, and restore administrative flexibility before demographic and economic pressures peak
